options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A great course covering early definitions of "Hinduism" to Modi's government today. Really really interesting material, especially for a non-Indian like myself with little background. But the class is good for people of all backgrounds because Dr. Gandhi makes the material accessible, but also allows you to go as in-depth as you want.
Understanding of the development of Hindu nationalism from its inception in British colonial India to the present day

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Dr. Gandhi. She is a fountain of knowledge about literally everything! But she is also very kind and understanding, and adjusted the course to fit the moment during the strains of COVID. The course and readings were very interesting. Her mini-lectures on the topics were VERY helpful, especially with the confusing bits at the beginning.

Weaknesses: The beginning of the class was a bit scary for someone with no background since many of the concepts and words were very new. But it quickly got less intimidating, especially as we moved forward in time. Also the mini-lectures really helped.

Strengths - fascinating readings, great discussions, high level of student engagement
Weaknesses - none!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Mini lectures were very helpful! Perusall was also good.
Perusall annotation assignments and asynchronous lecture videos before class provided a great launching-off point for discussion during class time

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Totally! Great professor, really interesting material. Just be aware it might be very new if you are not an RLST student or Divinity student. However, I am neither and I loved the class. Really important stuff to learn about, and the professor made it an even stronger class. Dr. Gandhi rocks! This is an important topic and everyone should have a grasp about what's happening to "The World's Largest Democracy." It's scary.

Yes! This course is a thoughtful and thorough exploration of the origins, development, and effects of Hindu nationalism. Dr. Gandhi is so knowledgeable and did a fantastic job of keeping student engagement and participation high, even in a virtual format. All readings and assignments were obviously selected with care to make the most of our time. The midterm and final are very open-ended so you can explore whatever facets of the topic most interest you.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminars supplemented by some asynchronous recorded lectures
